{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3267174,"name":"Praveen P","username":"Jeeh","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/85f322/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-12-19T21:11:15.053Z","cooked":"

Hello,

My team is currently trying to implement a simple trajectory following with a tank drive. Our code is based on some example code from Team 2059. When we try to follow a trajectory of just moving straight forward 1 meter, the robot will go almost 4 meters instead. The encoder values also read 4 meters, so we don’t think the conversion factor is the issue.

We get out Ka, Kv, and Ks values from sysid but the kP seems to be very low (0.09), and we don’t know why. Everything else looks correct.

Here is our code: Here

That code is not using PathPlanner, I just want to be sure it’s the right code. The code you shared is using WPILib trajectories, and there also is no code to ever execute the RamseteCommand.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-12-19T21:35:55.657Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":133,"readers_count":132,"score":31.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":446599,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-moves-the-robot-the-wrong-distance","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/trajectories/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Trajectory Generation and Following with WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3},{"url":"https://github.com/mjansen4857/pathplanner","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - mjansen4857/pathplanner: A simple yet powerful motion profile generator for FRC robots","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-moves-the-robot-the-wrong-distance/446599/2","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3267218,"name":"Praveen P","username":"Jeeh","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/85f322/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-12-19T22:21:54.961Z","cooked":"

Sorry about that, we meant that we are using path planner to generate the JSON files, but WPILib trajectories for following. About executing the Ramsete Command, we removed the chooser and didn’t yet update our getAutonomousCommand function. Just updated the code, thanks. However, it still does not go the correct distance.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-12-19T22:21:54.961Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":446599,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-moves-the-robot-the-wrong-distance","display_username":"Praveen P","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44380,"username":"gdefender","name":"Andy Gasser","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56114,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 2720 Software & Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-moves-the-robot-the-wrong-distance/446599/3","custom_user_title":"Team 2720 Software & Strategy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3267321,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-20T02:35:45.828Z","cooked":"

I see an issue with your right encoder value. The encoder value is being inverted in getRightEncoderPosition() and getRightEncoderVelocity(), but it is not being inverted in any of the places it is used with DifferentialDriveOdometry.

Did you check where the robot’s odometry thinks it is? I would be willing to bet it thinks the robot is spinning in a circle until the trajectory time expires.

There are many ways to resolve this, but here’s what I recommend:

  1. Remove the MotorControllerGroups. You already have the front motors following the back, so just pass the back motors into the DifferentialDrive. You don’t need a group.
  2. Invert the rightBackMotor. By inverting the motor instead inverting a MotorControllerGroup, it will also invert the encoder.
  3. Remove the inversion from getRightEncoderPosition() and getRightEncoderVelocity. It won’t be needed because the encoder will now be in phase with the motor.

Thank you, this helped quite a bit. We tested a trajectory JSON created with Pathplanner going 1 meter straight and it went 1.5 meters instead, so we tried to manually create the trajectory, which worked. However, when we try a curved path (like the one in the WPILib documentation), it falls a little short (2.4 meters instead of 3).
